Hi Dan,

Thank you for the reply. 
 
> If the third party class doesn't provide this, then it gets
trickier.
>  You might be able to subclass the third party class and override
> the methods you want - but this is often very dangerous and brittle,
> if it will even work at all.  You might be able to use a bytecode
> generation tool like jMock with CGLib to create mocks of classes,
> though it's almost always easier to build off an interface.

This is going to be a problem for me. There is not direct interface
for the third party library. I have thought of direct inheritance but
not sure if it is a good idea. Using JMock and CGLib for bytecode
generation required some time to implement. Unfortunately, I don't
have the time now. Probably after my tight deadline then I will look
into it. Could you elaborate a little bit how you would approach this
problem using JMock and CGLib?

The good news is I am using Spring Framework in my application. I
could use dependency injection to inject the third party classs into
my class. If I don't have the interface for the third party, Spring
would still inject the implementation class for me using CGLib instead
of dynamic proxy, right?

Thank you for your help and the book information.

Regards,
Lee
